a: Common symptoms of a C. diff infection include diarrhoea, high temperature, loss of appetite, feeling sick, and a stomach ache.

q: How can someone get a C. diff infection?
a: C. diff bacteria usually live harmlessly in the bowel, but taking antibiotics can disrupt the balance of bacteria and cause an infection. It can also spread from person to person through contact with contaminated objects or surfaces.

q: Who is at risk of getting a C. diff infection?
a: People over 65 years, those taking or recently taken antibiotics, those staying in hospitals or care homes for a long time, those with weakened immune systems, and those taking certain medications are at a higher risk of getting a C. diff infection.

a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or contact NHS 111 if you have diarrhoea while taking or recently taken antibiotics, if you have bloody diarrhoea or bleeding from the bottom, or if you have diarrhoea for more than 7 days.

a: A doctor may test a sample of your poo to confirm a C. diff infection. Treatment involves stopping the current antibiotics, taking a 10-day course of another antibiotic specifically for C. diff, and staying hydrated. In severe cases, hospitalization may be required.

a: Symptoms should improve a few days after starting the new course of antibiotics, but it may take 1 to 2 weeks for the infection to completely clear up. If symptoms worsen or return, you should see a GP for further evaluation and potential repeated treatment.
